campaign.story:
“Werewolf is a simple game for a large group of people (seven or more). It requires no equipment besides some bits of paper; you can play it just sitting in a circle. I’d call it a party game, except that it’s a game of accusations, lying, bluffing, second-guessing, assassination, and mob hysteria.” – Andrew Plotkin, creator of Werewolf
"Use this deck." - Shawnimals
"Totally just backed." - Chris Messina
"Launched and funded at PAX East." - Polygon
"This set is an absolute must have." - Mike Trotzke
"Werewolf. By Max Temkin. On Kickstarter. That is all." - Chris Shiflett
"Finally, Werewolf cards that don't look terrible. Bravo" - Dan Sinker
Werewolf
Werewolf is a simple party game for 7 to 20 players. Werewolf is a folk game - it's based on Mafia, which was created by Dimitry Davidoff in 1986, and became Werewolf at the hands of Andrew Plotkin in 1997. The game has gone on to become a staple of tech conferences and gaming conventions, and many players, including myself, consider it to be one of the most difficult and elegant games ever created.
There are dozens of published versions of Werewolf, but I think many of them are overcomplicated and ugly, and some even require special parts and pieces to play.
I'd like to make my own set of simple, beautiful Werewolf cards, and get them to you affordably.
Each set comes with 20 cards in a custom zipper case, with a keychain loop so you can hook it on to your backpack. The roles included are:
Three werewolves
One doctor
One seer
One witch
14 villagers (7 male, 7 female)
To help teach people about my favorite game, I've also created an open source compendium of information about Werewolf. You can read the rules and more at Maxistentialism.com/werewolf.
Thanks
I got a tremendous amount of help from the Chicago design community prototyping and making these cards. Jana Kinsman created the amazing illustrations and collaborated with me on the overall design. Rob Loukotka lent me the the use of his laser cutter, Shawnimals let me use their corner rounder, and the Nerdologues helped me playtest the cards.
Thank you especially to Patrick Ewing and Fred Benenson for their help simulating the game and building the reactive rules. All of our work is available under an MIT license and available on GitHub - you can read more at Maxistentialism.com/werewolf.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Making Cards Against Humanity has taught me a lot about printing card games, and I already have a production prototype of Werewolf that I'm really happy with.

There's already about a million versions of Werewolf out on the market, and there's always a chance that nobody will want this one.

There are always risks of delays - figuring out shipping and keeping up with customer service has set previous projects back by a few weeks - but I think things should go smoothly!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Kickstarter Friends,
It looks like most backers have received their copies of Werewolf, and I'm seeing sets arrive this week in Bulgaria, China, and Argentina.
If you still haven't received your sets, I think it's safe to assume that something has gone wrong with your delivery. Please fill out this quick survey, and I'll send out a round of replacement sets at the end of the month.
Many of you have also asked how to get copies of Werewolf now that the Kickstarter has ended. I'm working on making some extra copies available, and you can sign up at  if you're interested!

Hey Kickstarter friends,
Werewolf cartons are continuing to arrive in Chicago! At this rate it looks like everything should be in by Thursday, and I may be able to begin shipping on Friday.

Hey Kickstarter friends!
It's been a long wait, but the finished, assembled games have begun to arrive here in Chicago, and they are awesome. About a fifth of the sets arrived in the office today, and the rest will be delivered on Thursday and Friday.
My mailing house in Chicago is standing by to receive these games and begin shipping - I'll keep you updated as I start transporting sets to the mailing house and they hit the mail next week.

Dear Kickstarter Friends,
Today Werewolf was funded at 21,225% of my original $200 printing goal. It finished with $42,451, making this my highest-funded project on Kickstarter.
I wanted to make these cards because I believe that Werewolf works best without any gimmicks or tchotchkes or special pieces and parts, and I'm really proud of running a simple Kickstarter for this simple project.

Kickstarter's policy is not that late projects must refund impatient backers. The policy is that if the creator cannot fulfill a backer's reward (the physical object, not the estimated delivery date) they must refund the backer. Conflating terms of use with creator guidelines is disingenuous. There's nothing in the terms of use requiring creators to update at any particular time interval, straight up. The creator FAQ (http://www.kickstarter.com/help/faq/creator+questions) says that "some creators may post every day, others may do it rarely", and Max has specifically said he will only update when there is new information. That's his right, and doesn't violate the terms of use.
As for CRAZY CAPS, yes, I capitalized a couple words and therefore all my points are invalid, gosh you are good at valid arguments!

On Kickstarter, as a project creator, you can take the money and run. There's nothing stopping you. Zion Eyez did it. You could too. I just really don't think you people have perspective... This Kickstarter is clearly active, whereas others I've backed have clearly cut and run. You don't like the complete lack of accountability? I love the whole "store/not store" debate. I think KS is AND isn't a store, depending on the project. In this case, this project had a $200 goal (extremely low) and soon had thousands of dollars pledged to it (the project was well beyond funded and at a certain point new backers were just buying the game). This project also might or might not be released in physical stores in the future. I can't be certain it will be anyway, who knows? In cases like this, Kickstarter is most definitely a store. When the project is, for instance, some kid trying to create a widget in his back yard and is struggling to meet funding, then Kickstarter is a project backing platform where you put dollars toward ideas you believe in. I'm not dumping on anyone, I'm excited about this project, I'm sure it will ship eventually, etc. I just think the KS "store/not store" debate is interesting.

@Thomas Some time after the project ends, you'll be sent a survey by Max to enter your shipping address and other things (for example, how many add-ons you are getting). Your card will be billed immediately at the end of the project, but the survey is usually a day or so after. Sometimes it's longer, but it's different for each project, so there's no way to know for sure. You'll get the survey before June 1, but as for when it ships, that's another story. My suggestion would be to enter an address of a friend/parent or a work address, since you likely won't know the address of where you're moving this early.

campaign.story:
"Do you have a charger I can use? "
"Oh no! I forgot my charger at home!"
"Wait one second, I have to run back in and get my charger."

Over the years we had accumulated enough Apple chargers that having a cable handy was never a problem.  However, with the release of the new lightning jack for the iPhone 5 we found ourselves back at square one... having to remember our charger every time we left home.  Within days of having the iPhone 5 we had no choice but make a new friend - Nomad:  An Apple certified cable that has no home.  
While the aesthetics of the Nomad was important to us, the most critical aspect of our cable design was to make it Apple certified.  We had purchased too many knockoff cables in the past that stop working after a month. Creating a quality cable that would last was a top priority.
"This Keychain Lightning Connector Is Perfect for Emergency Charges" - Mashable
"This is going to be a breakthrough product" - Apple Magazine
"This idea is simple but brilliant" - Tecnabob
"The Nomad is a must have!" - CRNCHY
The Nomad is a 3" Lightning to USB cable that caps securely to your key ring
The Nomad loves to nestle between your iPhone and laptop!
The Nomad charging from a USB port in a vehicle
Dimensions of the Nomad cable
Designing the Nomad in 3D CAD
Prototyping the Nomad
The Nomad is flexible enough to charge from almost any USB port!
Pledge $30 to receive a Nomad plus a custom aluminum bottle opener!
Potential Packaging Concepts
Up until now
We have established relationships with three different Chinese manufacturers who we see as potential partners in producing the Nomad. One of these manufacturers, a reputable producer of iPhone accessories, provided us with the prototypes that are pictured and filmed throughout our project page.
Once funding begins
We will closely review quotes from these three overseas manufacturers and finalize our assessment of who will be the best partner in producing the Nomad. We do not want to accept any quotes prior to achieving our goal in the event that we exceed our goal. This would allow us to offer more colors and options!
Once successfully funded
We will have chosen a manufacturer and will be able to immediately move forward with the tooling of molds - followed by a full production run. The entire production run will either be overseen directly by us or one of our overseas associates we have worked with in the past. From there, each Nomad will be tested, packaged, and sent directly to Chicago where we will box and ship them out to you within days!
With a successfully funded project, we will get our first run of Nomads manufactured, packaged, and shipped to your key ring by February 2013.  Our ultimate goal is to make the Nomad available in the retail market.
The Nomad cable is patent pending
SUPPORT@NOMADCABLE.COM
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Manufacturing:
It was extremely important to us to find an Apple Mfi certified manufacturer to ensure quality. The cost of our initial run is higher than we would prefer. However, we did not want to compromise the integrity of the cable. 

Cost:
Establishing both a retail and manufacturing cost were a big challenge. While we were able to establish relationships with overseas suppliers, production costs were not available until hours before submitting our final project.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Can't stop won't stop!
BREAKING NEWS: Thanks to your generosity, we have exceeded our goal!  We are on the floor with gratitude, but humbly, we ask you: if you can find it in your hearts to keep donating and keep shouting out, exceeding our $75K goal means we may be able to consider many aspects of great filmmaking that were previously unattainable to us.  With more money, we can hire more and better-paid crew members.  We can license songs and images to round out our 2004 landscape.  We can bring more people to our Wisconsin shoot.  And so much more.  Help Farah Goes Bang crack $100K to become one of Kickstarter's highest-grossing film campaigns of ALL TIME!
Exciting casting updates!
Our Farah is...Circumstance actress Nikohl Boosheri!  Circumstance, a forbidden-love story of two young women in Tehran, won a nearly outrageous number of 2011 film festival awards, including the Sundance Audience Award. It was named the year’s “most anticipated” independent film by the New York Times, and was one of Paste Magazine’s 50 best films of 2011. Nikohl’s was named Best Performance at both the Rome, LA OutFest and Noor Film Festivals. We know that Nikohl’s talent and stardom will help our film reach similar acclaim!
Kiran Deol, an actress, comedian and documentary filmmaker, will co-star as Roopa Raj, a political junkie who blazes a trail across America for the Kerry campaign in the hopes of earning a job at the John Kerry White House.  Deol, a graduate of Harvard University, directed the feature documentary Woman Rebel, which premiered on HBO and was nominated for an Emmy Award.  Kiran’s outsize intelligence and outrageous wit will illuminate the role of Roopa.
Grace Parra as Nancy
Samrat Chakrabarti as Anoop
Kate French as Katie
The press likes us:
Feministing
San Francisco Bay Guardian
The Sexy Grammarian
The Rumpus
Hyphen
Racialicious
The Faster Times
The Film Stage
IndieWIRE Project of the Day
Women and Hollywood
THE FILM
FARAH GOES BANG tells the story of Farah Mahtab, a woman in her twenties who tries to lose her virginity while on the road campaigning for presidential candidate John Kerry in 2004. Farah and her friends K.J. and Roopa follow the campaign trail across historic Route 66 on their way to Ohio, the central battleground state of 2004, seizing control of this charged moment in their lives and the life of their country. FARAH GOES BANG is Thelma & Louise meets Y Tu Mamá También meets On The Road: the film was co-written by Meera Menon and Laura Goode, will be directed by Meera Menon, and will be produced by Laura Goode, Liz Singh, and Danielle Firoozi.  
FARAH GOES BANG is a valentine to contemporary feminism, youth in revolt, and the passionate politics of idealism. It is the travelogue of three women out on a highway belonging not to suicidal housewives or bubblegum pop stars, but to young women as agents, as doers, as authors of their own American odyssey. In this way, FARAH updates the classic American tradition of the Western, telling a new trail story--whose subjects are both cowgirls and Indians, both heroines and outlaws--in a diverse, powerful, and hilarious female voice.  
OUR CAMPAIGN
With this campaign, our team aims to raise $75,000 or more in the month of April to fund production of the film in June and July 2012. Visit our website at www.farahgoesbang.com to learn more about the film, the community we’re building with our blog, Cherry Bomb, and the conversations we’re having on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and YouTube. 
WHO WE ARE
The FARAH GOES BANG project is an intensely personal one for co-writers Meera Menon (director) and Laura Goode (producer), who have been friends, collaborators, and sometime roommates for almost ten years, and who have dreamed of making a movie together for pretty much all of those years.  After producing four short films and a full-length play together, receiving our respective MFAs in film and writing, and spending two years co-writing the FGB script, it feels uniquely appropriate for us to be making a film about friends who make each other laugh, tell each other secrets, and constantly challenge each other to grow. 

HOW KICKSTARTER WORKS
It’s easy: all you have to do is sign up for a free account, give any amount you can, and claim your reward. Your donation amount will not be publicly displayed, and we receive your funds only if we meet our full $75,000 goal. If you’d rather not claim a reward, you’re welcome just to donate, and if you’d like to increase your donation at any point during the campaign, just sign in, come back to this page, and click the blue “Manage Your Donation” button to enter a new amount or choose a new incentive.

CONTACT US
We love hearing from our supporters and prospective supporters, and have always hoped this film would inspire lots of new conversations.  Please contact us at farahgoesbang AT gmail DOT com with any questions whatsoever, and visit our website, Facebook, and Twitter pages frequently for updates on the film, Cherry Bomb, and much, much more.

From the bottoms of our exploding hearts, thank you for visiting this page and considering making a donation.  We’re building a dream, a business of ideas, and are more grateful for every supporter than you will ever know.

Yours in imagination,

Laura Goode + Meera Menon
Co-creators, FARAH GOES BANG
And the FGB production team:
Liz Singh and Danielle Firoozi, Producers
Neelanjana Banerjee, Editor, Cherry Bomb
Mike Fabio, Community Manager
Paul Gleason, Director of Photography
www.farahgoesbang.com

updates.update_userinfo: It's Farah's day! BUY or RENT FGB on iTunes!!!
updates.update_content:
Dear fellow road-trippers of Farah Goes Bang,
The day is here.
The time has come.
Farah Goes Bang, our baby, no longer belongs to us, but to you.

updates.update_userinfo: LA premiere of Farah Goes Bang, & final call for claiming rewards!
updates.update_content:
Our dearest venerable backers,
Greetings from Farah Goes Bang, where we still are traveling the country, showing our movie, and getting great responses everywhere we go! Most recently, we are proud to say that we won Best Narrative Feature at CAAMFest, sponsored by the Center for Asian American Media in San Francisco. Laura and Meera were presented with the award at the historic Castro theater (see below). In addition, we recently learned that we also won the Bud Abbott award for best feature length comedy at the Garden State Film Festival in Atlantic City!

updates.update_userinfo: Farah flies north for the winter. Like a very confused bird.
More festivals and fun!!! Bend, Twin Cities, Toronto, and more...
updates.update_content:
Dear backers,
In true FGB style, we've been road-tripping all over America for film festivals this fall--we've had an amazing time at Orlando's Global Peace Film Festival, the Chicago South Asian Film Festival, the Hell's Half Mile Film Festival, the Mill Valley Film Festival, and this very weekend, BendFilm in Bend, Oregon! 
BUT WAIT! We have even more festival fun coming up. Please join us if any of these screenings are taking place in a location near you!

updates.update_userinfo: Farah Goes Bang fall festival tour!
updates.update_content:
Beloved backers,
We hope you've been receiving your long-awaited rewards, and that you are enjoying all the delectable goodies your support for FGB has earned you, most of all the film itself! If you love what we've sent you, we'd be delighted if you took a moment to like our Facebook page, post or tweet how you felt about the film, or even send us a note sharing your thoughts. We're thrilled to be able to finally share the film with you.

updates.update_userinfo: Rewards for YOU, and Glamour's 35 Under 35!
updates.update_content:
Hey again, favorite backers!
We're in the middle of the Tribeca craziness now, and loving every minute--we had an incredible premiere on Friday (red carpet pic attached!) and are still going full speed.
Do you want to see Farah Goes Bang?  If yes, pick from these two very special options!
1) If you're not in NYC, PLEASE watch and rate the film from afar!  You can watch FGB for FREE on Tribeca's website until April 28. We're up for a $10K Audience Award, so please give us 5 stars!!!

Dear best backers ever,
We have so much to share with you!
First, the OFFICIAL FARAH GOES BANG TRAILER for the 2013 TRIBECA FILM FESTIVAL!!! Watch it, share it, love it.  It loves you back!
Next, here is the complete screening and ticket information for our Tribeca showtimes! Tickets go on sale this for American Express cardholders, and for the general public.

campaign.story:
Hey friends, family, and Kickstarters! You may remember seeing a page very similar to this one just several months back. Earlier this year, we were fundraising to launch production on an ambitious short film project titled The Handout Saint, and now we're back after months of preparing, shooting, and editing, to finish the project and submit it to several dozen major film festivals. 
For those of you not already familiar, The Handout Saint tells the story of Felicity Adamson, a young woman living in New York City who suffers from a rare condition in which she's predisposed to developing addictions to just about anything she finds enjoyable. After numerous battles with substance abuse and bizarre addictions, she turns to compulsive charity as her new high, and has a profound encounter with reciprocity.
The film is just a hair from completion, requiring only a final color grading job, and  a final audio mix featuring original music currently being finished by our friends with FREE BLOOD (Check out "Never Hear Surf Music Again" from 127 Hours). We only need about $2,000 to put the finishing touches on the film, a part of which we are trying to raise right here on Kickstarter. 
Even great films are pointless if nobody sees them, so we're also raising as much as we can to help pay for festival submissions and exhibition expenses (digital prints, venue rentals, key crew travel for festivals). We've worked very hard on a project we believe in, and we'd love to have your support in taking it worldwide! 
We've set a pretty low minimum, but keep in mind we have no maximum. Your liberal giving is sincerely appreciated. 
Here's where we plan to submit to (so far):
